# Prediction {.transition}

## Prediction in the L1

::: {.fragment}
Humans constantly [predict]{.emph} non-linguistic [@bar2007proactive; @lee2003hierarchical] and [linguistic]{.emph} information [@van2012prediction; @altmann1999incremental]
:::

::: {.fragment}
Extant research suggests that intonational information is [processed in real-time]{.emph} [@esteve2020empathy; @grodner2010some; @kamide2003time; @crocker2010computational; @levy2008expectation]
:::

## Prediction in the L2

::: {.fragment}
L1 German L2 English [CEFR B2 or above; @councilofeurope2001cefr] learners [predict]{.emph} referent based on contrastive pitch accent [in L1]{.emph}, but [not in L2]{.emph} for the same sound-to-meaning prediction [@foltz2021using]
:::

::: {.fragment}
In contrast, @klassen2015second found that L1 Spanish L2 English learners [predict]{.emph} referent based on contrastive pitch accent [in L2]{.emph}
:::

## Prediction in the L2

::: {.fragment}
The cues matched in the L1 and L2 in both studies... so why the difference?
:::

::: {.fragment}
- The Spanish-English bilinguals had [more time]{.emph} to predict in the task [@foltz2021using]?
- Difference in [proficiency]{.emph}?
- Difference in [language exposure]{.emph}?
:::

## Prediction in Interpreters

::: {.fragment}
- Interpreters are seen as [expert predictors]{.emph} [@dong2020attentional; @setton2005pointing]
:::

::: {.fragment}
- We can use interpreters to [control for proficiency]{.emph} so that we can look at [language exposure]{.emph}
:::

::: {.fragment}
- Interpreters are expected to take advantage of all aspects of the signal, including prosody [@riccardi1997lingua; @kohn1996strategic; @gile1992predictable], but there is a lack of [experimental research]{.emph}
:::

## Prosody and Prediction in Interpreters

::: {.fragment}
- @seeber2001intonation tasked German-English interpreters with [monotonous]{.emph} vs [lively]{.emph} source texts and examined rates of prediction and accuracy of verb, but found no difference
:::

::: {.fragment}
- Unfortunately, the connection between intonation and verb prediction was not motivated and sample size was small
:::

::: {.fragment}
- L1 English L2 Spanish interpreters make use of first syllable's prosodic pattern to predict suffix [@lozano2023interpreting; @lozano2021interpreting; @lozano2020slowly]
:::

## Language Exposure, Prediction, & Interpreters

- The more often one (accurately) predicts, the more frequently they will make the same predictions based on the same cues [@roettger2019evidential; @bar2007proactive; @lee2003hierarchical; @van2012prediction; @altmann1999incremental; @gruter2021prediction]

# Research questions {.transition}

:::: {.r-fit-text}

::: {.incremental}

1. Do L1 Spanish monolinguals recruit early intonational cues (i.e., first F0 peak and presence/absence of medial pitch accent) to predict sentence modality?

2. Do L1 English L2 Spanish late learners recruit early intonational cues (i.e., first F0 speak and presence/absence of medial pitch accent) to predict sentence modality?

3. Is the recruitment of the identified early intonational cues in L1 English L2 Spanish late learner dependent on experience interpreting questions from Spanish to English?

:::

::::

# Methodology {.transition}

## Participants 

::: {.incremental}

- 30 L1 Madrid Spanish speakers
- 60 L1 UK English L2 Spanish professional interpreters
  - 30 working in Madrid
  - 30 working in Gibraltr

:::
